resources.string: Your device does not support this sensor
Please allow microphone permission to use this sensor
Please allow location permission to use this sensor
This sensor measures spatial sound information around you. Your device uses the microphone to make this work. The sound information is then converted into decibels (dB).

A decibel is a logarithmic unit of measurement used to measure the loudness of sound. Whether you\'re close up or far away from a sound source you can use this to get an idea of how intense the sound is. Note that Android microphones are limited to a maximum of 90 dB!
The Air Temperature sensor uses your phone\'s hardware to find the ambient temperature you\'re currently in. This will work anywhere even without being connected to an internet source!

Example use cases include determining if your home is cooling properly, industrial space/enclosure readings, and finding outside temperature while offline. Please note that these readings may be slightly off as your smartphone may have heat stored near the hardware\'s sensor! Smartphone cases may also factor higher output readings!
This sensor requires no calibration or modification to interpret light data. It will measure lux (light) from any distance and return to you its intensity.

The values of lux will differ wildly depending on the ambient light information your smartphone absorbs. Your living room may measure anywhere from 1–150 with a few light sources on. Going to a well lit office or show room may have a reading of 500 lux! Step outside and this may jump up to 25,000! This sensor can be useful for planning out rooms and spaces to meet certain lighting standards.
RAM (Random Access Memory) is constantly consumed and in use for every mobile device. This sensor measures the amount of memory currently available on your system.

This sensor is geared toward those curious about how much RAM is being used by the system. A portion of RAM is always in use because of the Android OS powering your phone providing functionality as you use it. The more RAM your device has available the more apps can run in the background!
This sensor is similar to the Air Temperature sensor. This provides an easy way to gauge how hot your device is at any given time.

If your device is too hot you may consider lowering your screen brightness, disconnecting from wifi/data, or close a game that is running. You may also use a fan or cool air to lower battery temperature. Environmental temperature has a great influence of your device\'s battery temperature!
The Accelerometer sensor is a handy tool for determining your speed output. This works by gathering GPS data based upon your location and converting your speed into a tangible number.

Some use scenarios include tracking car speed accuracy and finding your top running speed. Note that because this is only as accurate as your connection to wifi/data the sensor may or may not be as accurate as it could be!
Barometric pressure (also known as atmospheric pressure) is the force the atmosphere exerts at any given point. You can think of this as the weight of the air.

This sensor is helpful for a number of reasons. Lower pressure is associated with a higher amount of headaches, joint pain, and lower blood pressure! This can also be used to help generally predict weather: A rise in pressure can mean an improvement in weather while falling pressure could mean incoming weather. This reading will vary with altitude and moisture levels.
This sensor calculates the relative humidity around you without the use of wifi or data. This information is given to you in the form of raw data.

Humidity is the amount of water vapor residing in the air. A value of 100% means the air is thoroughly saturated with water and cannot hold any more. Clouds form at this percentage! Though the temperature is also higher as a result. Low values can make us feel cooler than the actual temperature and gives way to dry air which in turn helps evaporate sweat!
The Step Counter is a simple tool to calculate the amount of steps you\'ve taken at any given time.

You can pin any sensor to your home screen by long pressing the icon
